Movie review Isle of Dogs a mechanical phenomenon | Charlotte Observer

March 29 2018 04 00 AM Wes Anderson has returned to cinema with his highly anticipated film Isle of Dogs. Following the story of a young boy in the age of the Japanese Archipelago the film tells the story of a future in which the dog flu has plagued canines and deemed them unable to be house pets. All of man s best friends are sent to Trash Island in exile to preserve human beings on the orders of the corrupt Mayor Kobayashi (played by Kunichi Nomura). Atari Kobayashi a 12-year-old boy sets out on an odyssey with a stolen plane to find his missing dog Spots. He crash lands on the forbidden island and enlists the help of five alpha canine companions Chief (Bryan Cranston) Rex (Edward Norton) King (Bob Balaban) Boss (Bill Murray) and Duke (Jeff Goldblum). Wes Anderson s attention to detail and remarkable visual effects make Isle of Dogs an undeniable mechanical phenomenon. Anderson s aesthetic approach is carefully crafted to make each scene almost perfect symmetrical and compelling. The director s ability to design fictional worlds and combine them with fantastical scenarios and misfit characters is unparalleled and highlights the intrigue surrounding this film. The characters in Isle of Dogs have identifying qualities that make them distinctive adding to the offbeat and contrasting tone of the stop-motion picture. The film s Japanese setting also adds to its commendable efforts at exploring cinematic territories yet to be discovered. It s usage of Japanese language in a manner that is native to the story rather than disregarding it marks a commendable storytelling method. From the futuristic cities immoral leadership talkative tail-waggers and approach to human mistakes Isle of Dogs creates a plot that is both unpredictable and sensational paying a beautiful homage to Asian culture. The music of Isle of Dogs also manages to send audiences to a whole other world capturing a distinctive Japanese style with the heavy drums ominous flutes and vintage trumpets composed by Oscar-winning composer Alexander Desplat. Each theme channels the film s emotions thoroughly. The score along with the glorious optical sights and quirky dialogue create a film both unexpected and astonishing.
